I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help government agencies, 
through knowledge development and capacity building, to plan Sri Lanka’s recovery from the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and make systems resilient to similar crises in the future. The 
TA will focus on key sectors and address gaps in the system to ensure improved service delivery 
in the medium and long term. 
   
2.  The TA is aligned with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) policy paper, Comprehensive 
Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic.1 The policy paper articulates ADB’s support for its 
developing member countries in mitigating the economic, social, and health impacts of the 
pandemic.2 It is in response to the government’s request for TA to conduct assessments on 
sectors affected by COVID-19 for national development planning for recovery from COVID-19 
and building resilience. The TA will support the government’s approach of maximizing the use of 
existing government human resources. Where capacity is not available, the TA will be used to 
mobilize national experts; if national experts are not available, international experts will be 
mobilized. The TA is included in the ADB country operations business plan, 2021–2023 for Sri 
Lanka.3 The current country partnership strategy envisages the provision of knowledge support 
during the implementation period in line with government needs.4 The TA is aligned with the 
operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  While Sri Lanka successfully contained the first wave of the COVID-19 outbreak, the 
emergence of a new cluster in early October 2020 has put that success at risk. As of 25 November 
2020, Sri Lanka had 20,967 confirmed cases, with 15,447 recoveries and 94 deaths.6 Early 
implementation of stringent public health and strict lockdown measures helped contain the spread 
of the virus in the first half of 2020. However, disruption caused by COVID-19 and containment 
measures  adversely  affected  economic  activity  and  lowered  consumer  and  business 
confidence—limiting household income and consumption as well as private sector business sales 
and investment. Tourism suffered as arrivals fell by 63.1% year on year in the first 9 months of 
2020.7 The government response focused on support to the poor and vulnerable, including people 
who had lost income sources, by providing cash transfers and expanding existing social protection 
schemes, but the scale, scope, and duration of cash transfers limited the stimulus to the economy. 
The government placed greater emphasis on monetary policy measures and finance sector 
measures to support the economic response. It supported industries by providing subsidized 
loans and debt moratoriums.

2 
4.  ADB projects the economy to shrink by 5.5% in 2020.8 As with most crises, the poor and 
vulnerable  sections  of  the  population,  including  women,  feel  the  largest  impact  of  these 
developments. The poverty headcount ratio at the poverty line of $5.5 a day (in 2011 purchasing 
power parity) is expected to increase from 38.4% in 2018 to 41.3% in 2020.9  
 
5.  The fundamental development problem the government faces is recovering from the 
pandemic and making systems resilient to face future crises of a similar scale. While this will 
include policy responses to stimulate the economy and support sectors that continue to struggle, 
the government needs to identify gaps in the system and enhance the skills and knowledge of 
government officials to develop and implement plans and programs. Before the outbreak of 
COVID-19, the government had identified key policy areas in the National Policy Framework to 
guide the country’s development process.10 These priorities remain relevant and continue to guide 
the government’s recovery efforts. The policy areas prioritized by the National Policy Framework 
include (i) human resources development through better health care and education, (ii) agriculture 
and food security, (iii) improving the business climate, (iv) increasing exports, (v) tackling the 
budget deficit, (vi) value addition by small and medium-sized enterprises, (vii) women’s labor force 
participation, (viii) improving social protection and welfare, (ix) an integrated planning and spatial 
approach to address rural–urban gaps, (x) ensuring water for all for drinking and agriculture, (xi) 
strengthening disaster management and disaster warning systems, (xii) ensuring data availability 
for informed decision-making, and (xiii) mitigating the human–elephant conflict.11 A crucial aspect 
of the post-COVID-19 recovery will be the access to and deployment of vaccines through a well-
crafted vaccination strategy. 
 
6.  The government has requested ADB assistance to support its efforts toward economic 
recovery and improving system resilience. ADB needs to respond with curated knowledge 
solutions  in  a  time-bound  manner  and  provide  support  to  the  government  to  respond  to 
development issues successfully. The TA will support the government’s planning and policy 
formulation with analytical studies, policy briefs, and technical reports on sector and thematic 
issues in priority areas; undertaking surveys and data analysis; and capacity development of 
public officials.    
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030: (i) 
accelerating progress in gender equality (by making women more resilient to external shocks and 
promoting women’s economic empowerment); and (ii) strengthening governance and institutional 
capacity (through enhanced capacity and improved service delivery) (footnote 5). The TA will also 
contribute to the operational priority on addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities. 
The TA will contribute toward achieving the Sustainable Development Goals through capacity 
building and knowledge support in areas that support women’s empowerment and sustained and 
inclusive economic growth.  
 
8.  ADB has provided knowledge and capacity development TA to Sri Lanka through similar 
TA projects in the past. The TA for Support for Planning and Policy Formulation (Phase 1) had a 
wide scope to build government capacity in policy making, through knowledge products and

2020 Update: Wellness in Worrying Times. Manila; and Central Bank of Sri Lanka. 2020. Recent Economic 
Developments: Highlights of 2020 and Prospects for 2021. Colombo. 
9  Estimates by ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department. 
10 Government of Sri Lanka. 2019. National Policy Framework: Vistas of Prosperity and Splendour. Colombo.  
11 Because of increased deforestation, elephants encroach into human habitats for food—damaging crops, destroying 
houses, and sometimes attacking people, resulting in death. In response, people resort to actions that have resulted

3 
training.12 It was rated successful, and the TA completion report highlights the flexibility in the 
design that allowed the accommodation of a wide range of policy-related activities and quick 
responses to government requests.13 The TA for the Umbrella Technical Assistance Capacity 
Development Fund also had a broad scope, but was rated unsuccessful.14 The TA completion 
report noted that the implementation was affected by lack of output selection criteria, which were 
left to be determined during implementation, and lack of government ownership. Considering 
these lessons, the TA retains a flexible approach while ensuring government commitment through 
close  coordination  with  the  National  Planning  Department  (NPD)  during  the  design  and 
implementation. The ongoing TA for Supporting Delivery of Strategic Knowledge Solutions also 
provides capacity building and knowledge products, and has progressed satisfactorily.15 The TA 
will complement the work under the regional TA for Planning for Economic Recovery of South 
Asia from COVID-19, which will support the knowledge development and exchange for economic 
recovery plans and adjust development strategies.16  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: knowledge base and capacity of government 
agencies to respond to shocks and fast-track recovery enhanced (defined by TA). The TA will 
have the following outcome: capacity of government to support the preparation of policies and 
programs on systems strengthening and resilience enhanced.17 The outcome will be achieved 
through support for the training of government officials and the development of knowledge 
products. The achievement of the outcome will be measured through the contribution of these 
knowledge products and training programs to policy making. The first outcome indicator will 
assess if at least five of the recommendations from knowledge products are submitted for 
consideration by relevant government agencies for economic and social policy making by the end 
of 2023. The second indicator will assess if at least two analytical tools and methodologies that 
the government officials are trained on are applied in developing policies and programs by the 
end of 2023. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Technical studies, policy briefs, and other knowledge products on key 
sector and thematic issues prepared. The TA will identify and analyze critical issues that need 
to be addressed to achieve high growth and strengthen the country’s economic fundamentals 
according to priorities agreed on by the NPD and ADB. The assessments will focus on key sectors

outbreak and the change of government in November 2019.

4 
and produce recommendations that will strengthen the government’s capacity in policy making 
and program development on strengthening systems resilience.  
 
11.  The TA will support the production of printed copies, apart from the digital publications, to 
disseminate to relevant government agencies. About 50 copies of each publication will be printed 
to provide copies to all relevant government agencies, but the number may vary according to the 
dissemination plan as discussed in paragraph 13.  
 
12.  Output 2: Government officials’ knowledge and skills on systems strengthening 
and resilience improved. Based on requests made by the government, capacity building 
programs (including conferences, workshops, roundtable discussions, and knowledge sessions) 
will be conducted by resource persons to strengthen the capacity of government officials. Training 
programs will develop skills and provide analytical tools to enhance the capacity of government 
officials to support policy analysis and program development to strengthen systems and resilience. 
The output will be measured by the number of training activities conducted (at least five) and the 
effectiveness of these programs will be assessed from participants’ feedback.   
 
13.  Output  3:  Findings  of  knowledge  products  widely  disseminated.  Effective 
dissemination is crucial to ensure that the findings and recommendations of the studies are 
included  in  the  policy  dialogue,  and  feed  into  the  government’s  policies  and  programs.  A 
communication strategy for the dissemination of knowledge products will be decided by ADB in 
consultation with the government and will depend on the knowledge product. The dissemination 
plan  will  take  into  consideration  the  type  of  product,  target  audience,  and  the  prevailing               
COVID-19 environment.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000 of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind 
contributions. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The Ministry of Finance’s NPD will be the executing agency of the TA. ADB will administer 
the TA through its Sri Lanka Resident Mission. The resident mission will select, supervise, and 
evaluate  the  consultants;  and  undertake  knowledge  products,  organize  workshops  and 
knowledge events, and plan and undertake dissemination. The specific studies and capacity 
development events will be identified during implementation, in discussion between the NPD and 
ADB. While requests could come from line agencies, the activities will be discussed with the NPD 
for concurrence. ADB will discuss the arrangements for the selection of proposals, such as the 
screening criteria and process, with the executing agency during implementation.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Sri Lanka for Supporting National Development Planning toward Recovery from 
COVID-19, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
